data.text: This no-confidence vote was a chaotic detour. Now politicians must stop the relentless manoeuvring of the past 30 months & come together to secure a workable Brexit deal. That way we can protect investment, jobs & living standards from the damaging impact of no deal.

Uncertainty is throttling our economy and destroying jobs – not in the future but right now. Firms need to know for certain a cliff-edge exit will not happen. Business needs steady progress towards a workable Brexit deal - not a chaotic return to square one.

Today's delay of the Brexit vote is yet another blow for companies desperate for clarity. Investment plans have been paused for two and a half years.  Unless a deal is agreed quickly, the country risks sliding towards a national crisis.

If Labour is really to find solutions that improve lives, they must sit down with firms and understand what will drive productivity and investment. The answer lies in the partnerships, innovation, infrastructure and skills that drive growth. It does not lie in dogma.

Business has been resilient in the face of uncertainty, but Labour’s anti-business positioning is starting to bite. It’s time for pro-enterprise collaboration, not public proposals that set alarm bells ringing in boardrooms at home and across the world.

Rising wages are what everyone wants to see. But Labour is wrong to assert that workers will be helped by these proposals in their current form. Their diktat on employee share ownership will only encourage investors to pack their bags and will harm those who can least afford it.

Rejection of Chequers helps nobody. With time slipping away before Brexit, employers and employees alike need to see constructive dialogue. Pragmatism must come before politics. Every day lost in rhetoric is lost investment and jobs.

Good to see @theresa_may guarantee the rights of EU citizens living in the UK even in the event of no deal, which remains the worst possible outcome. All efforts must be on securing a withdrawal agreement.
The events of the last 24 hours have made one thing abundantly clear - negotiators on both sides must change tack. Rejection of Chequers helps nobody.
After heat of Salzburg, time now for cool heads on both sides. Accidental cliff edge must be avoided. Unlocking transition is priority to protect jobs and prosperity – let’s get on with it.
